<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 213, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The times taken by members of a large cycling club to complete a cross-country circuit have a normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) minutes. The times taken, \(x\) minutes, are recorded for a random sample of 14 members of the club. The results are summarised as follows, where \(\overline{x}\) is the sample mean.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 131, 645, 151]]<|/det|>
\[\overline{x} = 42.8\qquad \Sigma (x - \overline{x})^2 = 941.5\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 415, 182]]<|/det|>
Find a \(95\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|> A large number of students are taking a Physics course. They are assessed by a practical examination and a written examination. The marks out of 100 obtained by a random sample of 15 students in each of the examinations are as follows. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 134, 905, 247]]<|/det|>
StudentABCDEFGHIJKLMNO
Practical examination666324525976885148369172686760
Written examination635739504771876556397870616270
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 920, 291]]<|/det|> Use a sign test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, to test whether, on average, the practical examination marks are higher than the written examination marks. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 272, 920, 291]]<|/det|> [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A factory produces metal discs. The manager claims that the diameters of these discs have a median of \(22.0 \text{mm}\). The diameters, in mm, of a random sample of 12 discs produced by this factory are as follows.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 133, 831, 152]]<|/det|>
22.4 20.9 22.8 21.5 23.2 22.9 23.9 21.7 19.8 23.6 22.6 23.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Carry out a Wilcoxon signed-rank test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, to test whether there is any evidence against the manager's claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 860, 143, 878]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 860, 630, 878]]<|/det|>
State an assumption that is necessary for this test to be valid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|> Two companies, \(P\) and \(Q\), produce a certain type of paint brush. An independent examiner rates the quality of the brushes produced as poor, satisfactory or good. He takes a random sample of brushes from each company. The examiner's ratings are summarised in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 133, 767, 211]]<|/det|>
CompanyPoorSatisfactoryGood
\(P\)184364
\(Q\)222231
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 223, 146, 242]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 223, 850, 242]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether quality of brushes is independent of company. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 223, 920, 242]]<|/det|> [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 136]]<|/det|> Jade is a swimming instructor at a sports college. She claims that, as a result of an intensive training course, the mean time taken by students to swim 50 metres has reduced by more than 1 second. She chooses a random sample of 10 students. The times taken, in seconds, before and after the training course are recorded in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 149, 902, 256]]<|/det|>
Student\(A\)\(B\)\(C\)\(D\)\(E\)\(F\)\(G\)\(H\)\(I\)\(J\)
Time before course54.247.452.159.055.351.048.952.258.451.4
Time after course50.146.352.558.851.448.449.548.758.351.4
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 341, 144, 358]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 339, 688, 358]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, whether Jade's claim is justified. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 341, 920, 358]]<|/det|> [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 71, 725, 91]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[383, 98, 653, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{x}{4} (4 - x^{2}) & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 2,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 280, 182]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{Var}\big(\sqrt{X}\big)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 164, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 562, 92]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(Y\) is defined by \(Y = X^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 485, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the probability density function of \(Y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 107, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 186, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 574, 470, 592]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the median of \(Y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 920, 592]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
